awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Connecting 3D Simulations of Magnetized Disks and Jets with Direct Event Horizon Telescope Observations
awd_abstract_narration:
Black holes (BHs) are the most compact objects predicted by Einstein's theory of gravity.  Despite their tiny size, BHs are powerful actors on the cosmic stage.  Most galaxies have massive BHs at their centers.  Such BHs can drive outflows and jets that extend over galactic scales, and beyond.  The processes that link the most compact and the most extended scales originate near the BH event horizon.  Images of that region have only recently become available, thanks to the NSF-supported Event Horizon Telescope (EHT).  The team will obtain new EHT images that, for the first time, trace magnetic fields.  The team will conduct state-of-the-art simulations to compare to the new images.  This will provide strong constraints on conditions near the BH event horizon.  Senior team members will train junior team members.  The team will also partner with D.C.'s Koshland Science Museum to engage with students from groups underrepresented in STEM.

The team will (1) produce state-of-the-art simulations of BH accretion and jets with fully dynamical gas-radiation interaction that accounts for kinetic physics relevant to systems like Sagittarius A* and M87, (2) undertake polarimetric observations with the EHT to resolve BH emission on event horizon scales in Sagittarius A* and M87, and (3) apply the simulations to enable realistic modeling of the polarimetry.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This award focused on linking state-of-the-art simulations of black hole accretion and jets to Event Horizon Telescope (EHT) observations of M87* and Sgr A*. It developed full polarization imaging capabilities and new theoretical tools to connect EHT observations to 3D general relativistic magnetohydrodynamic (GRMHD) simulations. This work led to insights into how to constrain the properties of black hole spacetimes, their accretion flows, and their relativistic outflows using radio interferometry.

This project supported extensive student involvement in the EHT, which produced the first images of a black hole in 2019. These images revealed the "shadow" of the nuclear black hole in the M87 galaxy, which has 6.5 billion times the mass of the Sun. These images were featured on the front page of nearly every major newspaper in the world and provide the strongest evidence for the existence of supermassive black holes described by general relativity and the Kerr metric. It also supported student contributions to the first polarimetric images of M87*, which were released in 2021. The polarization pattern in these images conveys information about the magnetic field structure near the black hole, which is central to understanding the physical processes that drive black hole accretion and that form and power relativistic jets. The polarimetric EHT data processing, imaging, and analysis were all supported by this award.

Specific projects supported under this grant included: 1.) the development of new imaging algorithms for the EHT, 2.) a new scattering model for the Milky Way's nuclear black hole, Sgr A*, constrained using archival observations, 3.) development of open-source software to model interstellar scattering, 4.) two-temperature GRMHD simulations of M87* including a self-consistent electron heating prescription, 5.) polarimetric analysis of GRMHD simulations that quantified rotational symmetry to tightly constrain models using polarimetric EHT images, and 6.) studies of a black hole's photon ring and a pathway to precision tests of general relativity using radio interferometry.

Activities under this grant resulted in 34 peer-reviewed journal articles, including seven papers led by graduate students and four papers led by undergraduate students. It also supported numerous public outreach events around these results including presentations at the Orlando Frost Museum, an NSF virtual press briefing, and two Reddit "Ask Me Anything" (AMA) events on the EHT and ngEHT that invited the public to engage scientists and ask questions.
